HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 15,
1968

L

News Briefs
California College Invaded
Last week, over 100 black militants invaded the San
Francisco
State College, forcing cancellation of all classes and brought
police
tactical squads to the campus.
The militants, including students and off-campus sympathi
zers,
swarmed through several buildings when it became evident
that most
students were ignoring a strike called by the Black Student Union.
Groups burst into classrooms, demanding that teachers halt
activities and, in some classes, chased the professors from
the
building into a pouring rainstorm.
The strike grew out of suspension of a Black Panther member,
George Murry,from a post as English instructor.

SDS Cleared By Trustees
Last Monday, Maryland State College trustees stated that they
Would not pursue charges brought against the Towson
State College
Chapter of the Students for a Democratic Society by Vice
President
elect and Governor Spiro T. Agnew.
In a mid-October campaign speech, Agnew had charged
two
Towson professors with sponsoring what Agnew called
"an
organization dedicated to anarchy."
In the speech, delivered in Detroit, Agnew said, "It's about
time
We began to discourage the employment
of this kind of person in
our colleges and universities."
In the Monday statement by the Board of Trustees, however,
the
Board said it "has received no evidence that would justify any
action
against any faculty member of Towson State or the student
organization or the individual students."
"The Board reaffirms its confidence in Dr. Hawkins and
his
administratinn "

Four Strip for Nixon
Four persons stripped off their clothes in the Lower Broadway
district of New York,last Monday, and handed out an "open letter"
to President-elect Nixon saying that "anatomic explosions are better
than atomic explosions."
The naked demonstrators, three men and a woman,stood on the
sidewalk for 15 minutes and were daubed with body paints by a
woman who identified herself as Yayoi Kusama, a 28 year old
Japanese artist.
As a crowd of 150 people watched, Miss Kusama urged peace in
Vietnam.
One of the demonstrators said that the group had staged similar
nude "happenings" in various parts of the city.
"We've never been arrested," he said, "because the police can
never get anyone in the crowd to complain.

PAGE 3

Stanford Orders Study
of Military Research
By PHIL SEMAS
(CPS) Stanford University may
be moving toward a change in its
relationship with the Stanford
Research Institute (SRI), which is
known to do military research.
Acting Stanford President
Robert J. Glaser has set up a
committee of five ,faculty
members, five students, and two
administrators to study Stanford's
relationship with SRI. The
Institute is an independent,
non-profit organization affiliated
with the University.
Glaser announced his plans for
the study at an unusual
appearance before the student
legislatu'r'e. He said the
relationship "is one of concern to
many members of the faculty and
student body," but added, "the
issues are complex, with many
ramifications, and are not the
kind that can be resolved
overnight".
Up Against the Door
Earlier, in an interview with the
Stanford Daily, Glaser said the
relationship "is a legitimate issue
to examine—not one to sweep
under the rug and say it doesn't
exist".
He said the incoming Stanford
President, Kenneth Pitzer,
supports the study. SRI Executive
Vice President Welcon Gibson
said the Institute would
"cooperate fully" with the study
which is supposed to be
completed by April 15.

E

Glaser's announcement came
shortly after the Stanford Chapter
of the Student for a Democratic
Society had demanded that the
University, SRI and "all members
of the University community
immediately halt all military and
economic projects and operations
concerned with Southeast Asia".
SDS nailed its demands to the
door of the Board of Trustees
office. It also demanded that all
contracts, classified and
unclassified, be made public,,
including the value of the
contract and the individuals
performing the work; that
Stanford and SRI trustees make
public their corporate and
government connections; and that
:Stanfordcl faculty also make
public their corporate and
government connections.
Glaser claimed his decision has
nothing to do with SDS's
demands.
Little Support
SDS seems to have little
support among the student body.
A rally they held to support the
demands drew only about 200 of
Stanford's 11,300 students. And a
Stanford Daily poll, based on a
computer-selected sample of 123
students, showed only 23.5 per
cent of the student body support
the SDS demands, 66 per cent
oppose them and 10.5 are
undecided.
Stanford student body
president, Dennis Hayes, would
also like to see some changes in

1

campus was research. At a
meeting held shortly after Glaser
announced this study Hayes aced
the Board of Trustees to use their
influence to get SRI to refuse to
accept new research contracts
involving chemical, biological or
counter-insurgency war fare
research until its study is
completed.
SRI Research
In making its demands, SDS
charged that SRI ,does chemical
and 'ioiOiOgical 'research including
tear gas and crop defloiiation; has
a staff of 5.
5 'doing
counterinsurgency work in
Thailand; is performing cost
analysis for alternative bombing
sites in North Vietnam; and is
doing long-range surveys of
investment opportunities in
Southeast Asia for U.S.
corporations.
SRI is presently conducting
about 700 research projects worth
about $65 million. About 73 per
cent of its support comes from
federal, state and local
government, the other 27 per cent
from private citizens. About
one-third of its projects are
classified. Vice President Gibson
said "a handful" are so secret that
even their existence cannot be
revealed.
About 50 Stanford professors
serve as consultants on various
SRI projects and almost 20 SRI
staff members lecture and teach
at the University.

Students Disrupt UConn
On Monday, November 11, over 100 student demonstrators
occupied the University of Connecticut's administration building,
saying they would not leave until amnesty was granted to four
professors and eight students involved in a protest against the Dow
Chemical Company last month.
The students roamed through the administration building
unchallenged, occupying the kitchen, administrative offices and the
conference room of the board of trustees, where they sat eating
doughnuts and drinking coffee.
Edward V. Grant, the school's Provost, said that the charge
against the professors was that they entered a room occupied by a
Dow recruiter and refused to leave, thereby obstructing a university
activity with "full knowledge" that it violated university policy.
On Monday, administrative work continued and officials made no
effort to evict the demonstrators.

Integration "Minimal"
Harold Howe, retiring after three years as U. S. Commissioner of
Education, says that his struggle to integrate public schools has been
disappointing, frustrating and "to a degree unsuccessful."
"Progress has been minimal," he told UPI. "Some 85 percent of
the Negro youngsters in the South still go to almost fully segregated
schools. In the North," he added,"the picture is much the same."
"We are still confronted with a school system in the United States
which is divided on a racial basis."
The 50-year old educator dismissed as campaign oratory
President-elect Richard Nixon's pledge that, as President, he would
not use federal money to force schools to integrate.
"I don't want to get into an argument with him because I don't
think the remarks he made were really carefully examined."

Dr. Johr P. Young, Associate
Provost of JHU, is doing a
study concerning
feasibility
Hopkin's role in the allied health
fields.
Money for increased health
facilities in the U.S. was approved
by congress in 1966 but money
has not been appropriated as yet.
Given the proper political
situation in the future, The goal
for adequate health facilities for
all may be realized. In Dr.
Young's opinion, society in
general has finally come to the
realization that proper health
treatment is a basic right of man
and the health field has already
become the — third largest
industry".
There is a great manpower
shortage in the allied health
servies. Hopkins already has
programs whereby people, many
of whom come from the inner
city, are trained to be technicians
and nurses aids. Many of these
trainees have only a high school
diploma and only some are given
certificates although all are given
jobs.
Of course Hopkins Medical
School, School of Nursing, and
School of Public Health train
many people to go into the field

of health mostly only on an
advanced level. Dr. Young
emphasizes that his report is only
seminal and will suggest possible
roles that Hopkins could assume
in training people for jobs other
than those of doctors and nurses
in the field of health. In the
process of making his report, Dr.
Young will take suggestions from
staff at the Hospital, School of
Public Health, and other people
familiar with health problems.
Dr. Young wants to arrive at a
proposal that will be approved in
principle by the Academic
Council at Homewood, The
Medical Advisory Board, and The
School of Hygiene Advisory
Board. If a general program is
agreed upon—if indeed Hopkins

HC ANSWERS
To The Editors:
The article last week in Veritas
by Howard Katz was an excellent
and insightful analysis of several
of the problems in our Honor
System. The Commission is very
concerned with these issues and
we are attempting to develop
viable solutions in our regular
meetings. Certainly the answers
are not simple and it is quite
helpful to receive the thoughts
and opinions of other concerned
individuals, such as Mr. Katz.
Mr. Katz presents the need for
the Commission to become more
"The Student's Honor
Commission," and suggests the
idea that a student should have
the option to submit his case to
the professor involved or to the
Honor Commission. This specific
idea has real value and is being
considered by the Commission in
committee. At an open meeting in
the near future it shall be fully
discussed and the Commission
hopes that all concerned members
of the community will
participate. Another problem in
the Commission related to the
idea of being more for "the
students" is the selection of
Honor Commission members.
Currently we are examining more
representative and appropriate
selection procedures and again we

would consider invaluable the
participation and contribution of
the community.
Mr. Katz also proposes that a
student should be able to report a
"course or a professor for
allowing cheating," either through
negligence or the structure of the
course. This is an excellent idea,
the mechanics for it do exist, and
it has been done in the past. If a
student feels there has been
cheating in a course, whether or
not he has factual knowledge of a
specific incident, he should report
it to the Commission. In the
Commission's investigation, then,
the problem is discussed with the
professor involved, and even if an
honor violation is not discovered,
the professor becomes aware of
the problematic situation. This
idea is really only one aspect of a
vital question now facing the
Commission. How far should the
Commission's authority reach in
attempting to influence and
further the academic environment
at Hopkins? Is the Commission's
place to encourage professors or
students to direct their academic
experience towards ideals
consistent with an Honor System
and a free learning atmosphere?
Or rather is the Commission
limited only to handling honor
violations when they arise?
Beyond these questions of general

aims, of course, are the practical
concerns for their realization.
This, then, is what we consider to
be the major problem the Honor
Commission faces and again
would encourage discussion
throughout the community.
Our next open meeting shall be
December 8, and I would like to
extend a personal invitation to
Mr. Katz, the Newsletter, and all
interested Hopkins' students,
faculty and administration.
Charles Steinberg
Honor Commission Chairman

Still Looking
The Students for a Democratic Society has grown both nationally
and locally over the past year; Hopkins SDS leaders attest to this,
even the New York Times noted the national growth in an article last
Sunday. It still garners a large share of publicity in its position as the
vanguard of the "movement." Yet, for those of us whose
frustrations grew during political 1968, what has it offered in the
way of an alternative? In what ways has SDS succeeded in
challenging what we see to be faults in our society?
On Election Day, SDS staged a demonstration in Washington and
other major cities across the United States. In Washington, they
succeeded in getting over a hundred people "busted." We say
"succeeded," because this clearly was necessary if SDS's objectives
were to be realized. Merely having a thousand people "voting with
their feet" would have done previous little to point up a choiceless
election; so people had to get arrested, Chicago-style.
In SDS's interpretation, the arrests show the "naked force" upon
which our system is based. And, perhaps, herein lies the limits of
SDS's capability as an alternative. SDS had no chance of any
measure of success insofar as influencing public opinion unless
authorities responded in a way that could be construed as repression.
So ... over a hundred people get arrested, a point is made about the
"system," -- what next?
At the risk of bringing down SDS's collective sneer of
"counter-revolutionary," we really cannot decipher "what is next"
as far as the SDS program of alternatives go. Possibly, as they claim,
they have succeeded in waking up or "radicalizing" more people.
However, it seems more likely that the Chicago police and the
cynicism of the major political parties has accomplished that
without much help from SDS.
Who has SDS succeeded in politicalizing? So far as can be
observed, only the middle-class white student who can presently
afford to be radicalized. SDS has had damn little effect on the black
people or the poor people. It can be pathetic sometimes to hear
Hopkins SDS members nostalgically point out how they started
UJOIN years ago — UJOIN being an inner city organization aimed at
helping the city's black people. Have they then succeeded in
appealing to the poor whites? Unfortunately, they have been a poor
• rival to George Wallace in this area.
As far as perceivable change is concerned, it seems that SDS has
only succeeded in titillating its own followers. The SDS script reads
like a staged play where the tool runs back and forth across the stage
screaming "Confrontation!" After the confrontation, then what?
What we see is a lot of frenetic activity and rhetoric,(as usually is
the case with rhetoric, it falls on deaf ears). SDS has failed to touch
the human, it has not helped to provide those in our society who
need help with means for bettering their lot, it has failed in its intent
to educate those who still believe that all is well in America. Instead,
SDS labors to analyze America with a semi-Marxist technique
despite the fact that the institutions they criticize fail to fit into
their given categories. The result is not only irrelevancy, but a failure
to intelligently convince those whom SDS looks to as potential
followers.
The Port Huron statement, issued at the birth of SDS, was a
discerning attempt to begin to develop a convincing and coherent
critique of America's problems. Whether one sympathizes with SDS
or not, it is obvious that they have failed to follow up on the
objectives which that statement outlined, or the tone which it set.
SDS has failed to provide students, or anybody else, with an
alternative that could be worked for, or even a goal which could be
realistically achieved.
Perhaps after the fabled "revolution," SDS might have something
to say; but that revolution is very fabled and perhaps that is where
the failings of SDS lie.

By JOHN HALPERIN
"Relevance" is a word we are
beginning to hear again and again
these days; it seems that all things
under the sun must stand or fall
on the basis of how "relevant"
they are. A recent New Yorker
cartoon, for example, showed a
student making a citizen's arrest
on a businessman for irrelevance.
Perhaps the increasing importance
of Relevance as a measure of
value is a result of this year's
political campaign; all six
candidates were to my mind
overwhelmingly irrelevant, and
undoubtedly their grey reflections
have shrouded the rest of us with
the question of what is relevant in
.1968 and what is not.
If Relevance is a'nattional issue,
it must of course also be one here
at Hopkins, which is in so many
ways a relevant "establishment"
oasis. I find myself in complete
agreement with the News-Letter,
for example, on the subjects of
R.O.T.C. and university defense
contracts. Neither, it seems to me,
has any relevance to the proper
functions and goals of a
self-respecting university. The
existence of either one or both
on any campus is, I think,
evidence that the university is
doing nothing whatsoever to help
diminish—is, in fact, helping to
perpetuate--war, the defense
establishment, and aggressive and

I

unenlightened foreign policies, all
of which ought to be among any
university's major targets for
oblivion.
I think any university
administration which reacts with
horror and threats to student
demonstrations or the suggestion
of them is in danger of becoming
not only irrelevant but obsolete.
Dr. Gordon has been guilty of
some of this, perhaps due to his
education in Lyndon Johnson's
State Department (the epitome of
Irrelevance); but Dr. Gordon
seems to have learned, lately, that
however appealing a university
without any students in it might
seem, it would not indeed be a
university. In the echelons just
below Dr. Gordon's--that
mysterious realm wherein several
hundred deans or so exist—there
seems to be, more consistently at
least, a laudably realistic and
compassionate attitude toward
student desires and needs, with
the result that the student now
has more influence upon his own
existence here than ever before.
On example of this is the decision
last year to establish an Appeals
Board for the freshman
dormitories, which would hear
complaints from domitory
students on disciplinary matters.
The Board itself, however, is
rapidly in danger of becoming
irrelevant; it has never met.

I also find guilty of Irrelevance
Dr. Eisenhower's Commission on
Violence, student-faculty
coffee-hours, the Ayn Rand
Society, Mr. Kravitt's recent
article on Joe Cowan, and
Thomas F. McDonough, whoever
he is.
People say the Student Council
is irrelevant, but J am not sure.
think it must be less irrelevant
than in past years. If it has made
mistakes this year, at least it
occasionally reminds us that it
exists. I find this year's
Orientation Committee, which
will not let us forget that it exists,
almost excruciatingly relevant; for
once we are seeing a truly creative
approach being taken with regard
to the question of the university
student's relationship to
essentially non-university
problems and issues. And I find
courses like "War in the Modern
World" relevant, courses that have
something to tell us about the
world we live in and are not
satisfied with asking us to define
"culture".
I find the News-Letter in
general, and Mr. Grauer's cartoons
in particular, relevant, and on rare
occasions--most often on
weekends—I even find myself
relevant; readers of this article
and my Friday afternoon
students, however, may well
disagree.

By RICHARD B.CRAMER
The Academic Council is the
most influential policy making
body on the Homewood campus.
The Council has two kinds of
meetings; the first is a formal
meeting at which resolutions or
motions are adopted and become
the policy of the University. The
second is an informal meeting,
during which issues are discussed
and accord reached so that
motions may be passed at the
next formal meeting.
On Tuesday, November 12, the
Council held an informal meeting,
to discuss "the role of students in
University policy-making." In
what amounts to a major
concession on the part of the
administration, two
undergraduates were invited to
attend. These students, Russell
Passarella (Remember? Inventive,
forceful RRRRussss?) and
Michael Amey (another campus
leader) were to serve as the
representatives of the student
body at the meeting.
Let us examine the
philo-political basis for this type
of representation. Naturally, the
Academic Council could not
entertain at its meeting, the views
of the entire student body. The
meeting would have become too
lengthy and too many students in
one place makes administrators
queasy anyway. So the Council
turned to your and our elected
leaders, the Student Council.
O.K.?

Fine, all a scale model of
Washington. But now let us cast
an eye on how this system works
in fact. Think back over the
months since you came to school.
Were you consulted as to your
opinion on the students' role at
Hopkins? Did you know that the
Academic Council was to grapple
with this question? Did you know
by whom you were to be
represented and how to make
your views known to them?
All right, we ask you for a
suspension of disbelief, now, and
suggest that you were, in fact,
amply represented at that
meeting. Suppose that by some
quirk of mass psychology, Mssrs.
Passarella and Amey represented
perfectly the view of the majority
of Hopkins students, even
without having consulted them.
We suspect that you would
want to know how your perfectly
represented views were received
by a group of men which is to
draw major policy guidelines on
the subject. There are two easy
ways to inform the students.
First, the members of the Council
could have asked a reporter from
the News-Letter to be present.
Not only was such a request not
made, but the News-Letter was
told that any of its staff members
would not be granted admission
to the meeting.
Second, our able
representatives could have taxed
their memories to the extent that
the News-Letter might have
printed the events of the meeting

to the best of their recollection.
Consulted early Tuesday evening,
Mr. Amey and a News-Letter
reporter conducted a conversation
thus: (Mr. Amey's remarks are
those erroneously labelled "A")
Q. Mike, could you tell tne
whether or not there were
any other students at this
meeting besides Russ and
yourself'?
A. There were two other graduate
students.
Q. What was the purpose of the
meeting?
A. Just to discuss the general role
of- the student in the
University.
Q. Was anything decided?
A. No, it was a very general and
relaxed discussion.
Q. Is anything going to come of
this meeting?
A. It was just a convenient basis
for an exchange of ideas, a
dialogue.
Q. Did you discuss student
participation in any
particular facet of the
University?
A. No,we didn't specify any
particular part of the
University, just general
points of information.
Q. What are these general points
of information?
A. What position students should
have in policy making in the
future.
Mr. Amey also did not know
when or if the Acadeniic Council
would again discuss this issue. We
thanked Mr. Amey for his help,

By BILL SAKOWICH
"Not with my life you don't!"

Sakowich was resting as he was
watching television at the end of
the summer. Due to a disability,
he had been laid off work for the
sununer, and was just hanging
around until school started agin.
He was in the process of sifting
the facts from the news media
trying to make a decision about
the actions of a free society in
Chicago during a political
gathering; and having just made a
mental analogy between Chicago
and Auschwitz, he noted that the
mail had arrived. Walking out to
the mailbox every day had
become a chore, and besides,
Sakowich was anxiously awaiting
his membership card in the
Teamsters. The letter that day
was not to be that delightful. It
was a letter from his draft board.
It was simply a letter for
reclassification of his draft status.
It took about five minutes to fill
out. Sakowich made the point
that he was a full-time student in
an accredited University. He
mailed the letter off immediately,
and went on in his preparations
for school.
His first hint that some
mistakes may have been made was
When his father called on a Friday
afternoon after registration was
completed. His father said—
"Hi, son, got a letter from the
*aft board today. You're 1-A."
"Oh, I see," his son replied.
(*Nieto*
Obviously a mistake had been
made. Not yet pushing the panic
button, Sakowich checked with
the Hopkins authorities. Sent to
his draft board almost
immediately were messages from
scf_._ 1,a___g)lalon with the proper

forms saying that indeed he was a
student. Sakowich also wrote an
appeal. At this point he was
rather confident that the mistake
would be rectified. He had
appealed in three days and was
allowed thirty.
The next day Sakowich again
received a phone call from his
father. He said—
"Hi son, I got another letter
from the draft board today.
You're ordered to take your
preinduction physical."
This time his son didn't say
anything.
He had not even been given
enough time to appeal. So
Sakowich wrote yet another letter
to his draft board. This time the
letter was not so polite.
Because his draft board was in
Virginia, and Sakowich thought it
rather ridiculous to appear in
person for a physical. So when he
received no reply from his letters
to Virginia, he decided to call the
draft board.
Southern Bell
He got in touch with the
matron who ran the show down
there. He could tell pretty much
what she was like from her voice.
She was about 40, with
fashionable gray hair, wore
knee-length flower print skirts, a
ring collar bouse with a Villager
sweater, brown loafers and
reading 'glasses; she had an
aristocratic southern accent, had
the job to begin with because she
knew the ruling political family,
and disliked Sakowich because he
was causing trouble for her, spoke
in a Northern accent; and above
all she realized that a Virginia
school wasn't good enough for
him. She said by way of
explanation—
"Whell whee din know jus

whut yall was doin this summuh.
Yew cooda been bununin aroun
owah demonstratin iowah
somthin."
"Uh huh."
"So yall get the deferment, but
yew owta take thet phizzicul. Idll
be good faw yuh."
`Uh huh."
"So get yowaseff a trayansfer
to Baltim owah, an take the
phizzicul theyah."
"Uh huh."
So Sakowich did. He got a
transfer and got reassigned to
Fort Holabird.
On the morning of the
physical, down he went to the
Baltimore Customs House, and
waited for the doors to open. As
he waited, a pacifist group handed
out leaflets that read,"You Don't
Have To Go". He talked to the
group, college students mostly,
except for a Negro matron, and
during the conversation a
policeman sauntered over and
took down the names of everyone
present.
Cop Out
"You in with this bunch?", he
asked Sakowich.
His only reply was a smile and
a shake of the head. After the
policeman left, the group went on
to explain that it was constantly
tailed by the F.B.I. Why? They
didn't know.
The doors had opened and
Sakowich went into the building.
He was slowly classified and then
boarded the bus for Holabird. As
the bus pulled away, one out of
the pacifist group raised two of
his fingers in a V-sign. A redneck
sitting next to Sakowich smiled
and said to him—
"How about that crazy

Sakowich ignored him.

Fort Holabird is not in an

looks as if Wallace would want to

Army architecture, looking like
i something Heinrich Himmler
might have dreamed up on an acid
trip.
Arresting Experience
So it all began for Sakowich.
Before the mental part began
everyone filled out a form
describing their previous arrests.
'During the test, the Army
administrator (with sideburns

pencil stuck in his left ear.

schtick. An Army Captain

"Haven't you been here
before?"
"Yeah, but I only got half-way
through."
"How come?"
"Aw, they had to take me to
the hospital, you know like I was
on Amphetamines."
After a snort of disgust the
Captain disappeared. Sekowich
talked to the anarchist after the
test and found him likeable
person.

The Johns Hopkins University
School of Medicine has received a
$259,652 grant from the John A.
Hartford Foundation, Inc. of New
York City for studies of lung
transplants.
Joint announcement of the
project and grant was made today
by Ralph W. Burger, Foundation
president, and Dr. David E.
Rogers, vice president for
medicine and dean of the medical
faculty at Johns Hopkins. Dr. R.
Robinson Baker, associate
professor of surgery, will direct
the project.
Dr. Baker said the transplant of
the human lung is technically
feasible and has actually been
attempted a number of times. In
his opinion, however, further
attempts should wait until several
basic problems have been solved
in the laboratory.
Within the past 10 years,
extensive experience with
transplantation of the lung in
experimental animals has been
accumulated.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 15, 1968

Engineering and Science at IBM

"You're treated
like a professional
right from the start'
"The attitude here is, if you're good enough to be
hired, you're good enough to be turned loose on a
project," says Don Feistamel.
Don earned a B.S.E.E. in 1965. Today, he's an
Associate Engineer in systems design and evaluation at IBM. Most of his work consists of determining modifications needed to make complex
data processing systems fit the specialized
requirements of IBM customers.
Depending on the size of the project, Don
works individually or in a small team. He's
now working with three other engineers on
part of an air traffic control system that will
process radar information by computer.
Says Don:"There are only general guidelines. The assignment is simply to come
up with the optimum system."
Set your own pace
Recently he wrote a simulation program that
enables an IBM computer to predict the performance of a data processing system that will
track satellites. He handled that project himself. "Nobody stands over my shoulder,- Don
says. "I pretty much set my own pace."
Don's informal working environment is typical of Engineering and Science at IBM. No
matter how large the project, we break it
down into units small enough to be handled
by one person or a few people.
Don sees a lot of possibilities for the future.
He says,"My job requires that I keep up to
date with all the latest IBM equipment and
systems programs. With that broad an outlook,
I can move into almost any technical area at
IBM—development, manufacturing, product
test, space and defense projects, programming
or marketing."
Check with your placement office
If you're interested in engineering or science at IBM,
ask your placement office for more information.
Or send a resume or letter to Paul Koslow, IBM
Corporation, Dept. C,425 Park Avenue, New York,
N.Y. 10022. We'd like to hear from you even if
you're headed for graduate school or military service.
An Equal Opportunity Employer

Blue Jays Bounce to Victory
Over Swarthmore's Ailing Line

Nest

By SKIP HUNT

Devotees of the running game got
to see speedsters Joe Cowan and
Paul Weiss run amuck through a
weak Swathmore line. And those
who prefer strong line-play and
heads-up defense were treated to
stellar performances by gameball
win ers John Peck and Willie
Scroggs and a host of other
defensive standouts.
But rather than gloat over the
gory details, the sports staff,
realizing the collossal nature of
the dawning weekend (The
Coming of Sergio, etc.) with the
help of Coach Sortir, has prepared
a spectator's guide to tomorrow's
game against Dickinson.

Thus far during the season, the
Blue Jays have built up a
reputation for introducing one
play a game that is so unexpected
that it is likely to change the
complexion of the entire contest.
And now all these plays are part
of a vast repetoire of surprise
tactics likely to be unveiled
tomorrow.
Key Plays
Off the wingback reverse came
the wingback reverse with
quick-kick, then the fake
quick-kick, and the wingback
reverse option-pass. Reverses on
kickoffs, dangerously exciting
wide pitchouts, and safety blitzes
are all part of the Jay arsenal.
New to this season is the
development of the fullback
position (filled by Mark Croft)
into an expanded role that
includes, in addition to blocking,
its own belly series up the middle
and a number of swing and screen
pass patterns.
Particularly valuable to the
basic Jay offense is the option
play (diagrammed here) in which
Feely, running parallel to the line
of scrimmage has the choice of
cutting upfield himself or pitching
to Cowan outside for a wide
sweep. The choice is based on
whether the unblocked outside
defender (No. 45) commits
himself to the inside or the
outside.
In amassing a 5-2 record, the
basic offensive pattern has been a
balanced mixture of Weiss inside
(with help from Croft) Cowan on
sweeps and counters (coming
back against the flow) and Feely

Frosh Eleven Whips B.1.A. Notes HopkinsExpectsRout
Of Devils Tomorrow
Clumsy PMC Squad
Last Friday, in their first home
game of the current season, the
freshman football team defeated
an inept and clumsy squad from
PMC Colleges of Chester, Pa., by
the score of 44-15.
From the opening kickoff to
the anticlimatic fourth quarter
there was not even the slightest
shread of doubt about the
outcome. The game began with a
fumble
by PMC Captain
Richie Weaver on the kickoff. Our
men thus had the good fortune to
begin play with the ball on the
oPponent's 5 yard line. On the
second play from scrimmage,
Steve Utz scurried into the end
zone for the first of his 3 ID's.
The extra points were missed and
the score was 6-0.
Weaver held on to the next
kickoff, and ran it back to the 30.
In the next three plays PMC was
only able to move several yards,
and so had to punt. Guard Bud
Cleveland, after a great rushing
exhibition, got his body in front
of the kick, from whence it
caromed to the PMC 11, where
Hopkins took over. On the next
Play, Bud Whalen floated the ball
to Steve Utz for another score.
On the screen, Joe Cieslowslci got
the extra points to make the score
14-0.
Once again, PMC managed to
hold on to the kickoff, and after
getting the premier first down of
the game, and after marching out
to their own 30, had to kick. The

ball's flight was unfettered this
time, but it didn't matter since it
was straight up into the air. When
the ball finally bounced out of
bounds the kick amounted to
minus five yards.
On the next play, Bud Whalen
threw the "perfect pass" to Dave
Pickall for the third TD out of
four bffensive plays, certainly a
great show of offensive power.
There was no more scoring
until the middle of the second
quarter when PMC recovered• a
fumble on the home 29 and
marched in to score on a 1 yard
QB sneak. They kicked for the
conversion. A Hopkins march was
then culminated by a five yard
score by Utz, his third TD. A
Whalen to Pickall 2 pointer
finished the scoring for the half
with the score 28-7.
The second half began where
the first half left off, with an 18
yard touchdown pass from Bud
Whalen to Dave Pickall, with
Butch Robey adding the two
points.
The Hopkins scoring finished
when Jeff Turshen pounded over
from the one after a 37 yard set
up run by Robey. Halfback Rich
Weaver then showed the speed
which had coach Bob Scott
worried, on a 70 yard pass play in
which he left the entire Hopkins
secondary behind.
The last game of the season
will take place today against the
Towson StateVarsity.

The results of the BIA tennis
tournament were: Sig Ep over Phi
Gam in the fraternities; Willard
over Wood in the upperclass
dorms; and Gildersleeve over
Adams in the freshmen dorms. Sig
Ep's Bob Tigner and Jim
Bernstein were the winning
fraternity doubles team. Winning
entrants for Willard were Simon
Tonkin and Stan Konefal. In
frosh competition, John Fischer
and Steve Kane teamed up to win
for Gildersleeve.
Basketball

Basketball will begin the week
of December 2. Any grad students
and independents who want to
form teams should contact Col.
Serena at the Athletic office.
Officials will be needed in large
numbers because of each teams'
increased schedules. Anyone
, interested in refereeing should
look for further notices in the
' BIA's scandal sheet, the gym, and
the News-Letter. Freshmen
refereeing will not conflict with
their playing for their respective
house. As of yet, the formal
schedules and league divisions
have not been made up by the
BIA.
Football Continues
A correction from last weeks
NOTES: Phi Ep was the winner in
the Charles Division, not ZBT.
The football schedule, especially
the fraternity playoffs and frosh
football, have been thrown off
base by the recent weather. Rain
and snow forced two
postponements of the Northern
Division playoff between ATO
(5-1) and TEP (5-1). In regular
season play, each house beat the
other once. TEP took the first
contest 15-6, but ATO came back
in the second encounter to win
19-18 in the final minutes of play.
Anyone who has seen any
ambiguities or discrepancies in the
BIA football rules and has any
criticisms or possible changes in
the rules is asked to drop a note
in Box 418, Gene Detroyer.

Hopkins now stands 4-4 for
the season, but has a winning 4 - 2
record in the Middle Atlantic
Conference. This places them a
respectable 5 out of 17 teams in
the league. Should the leaders

Our upstart congregation is too young and too small to
identify with the status quo. Founded in 1849, we have
only 6,000 members world-wide. Perhaps that is why,
responding to the needs of the changing times, we find it
easy to move out to where the action is. Among our favorite
assignments are the inner city and missions in Latin
America, where there's no shortage of injustice to confront.
We believe that Christianity, in the tradition of the early
, martyrs, must be somewhat anti-Establishment in every
age. We don't lock up our zealous young men for taking
this idea seriously. If you agree, we invite you to march
with us. Put down your brick and contact our vocations
director, Father Lawrence Hoge. Phone (312) 236-7782.

News Briefs
California College Invaded
Last week, over 100 black militants invaded the San
Francisco
State College, forcing cancellation of all classes and brought
police
tactical squads to the campus.
The militants, including students and off-campus sympathi
zers,
swarmed through several buildings when it became evident
that most
students were ignoring a strike called by the Black Student Union.
Groups burst into classrooms, demanding that teachers halt
activities and, in some classes, chased the professors from
the
building into a pouring rainstorm.
The strike grew out of suspension of a Black Panther member,
George Murry,from a post as English instructor.

SDS Cleared By Trustees
Last Monday, Maryland State College trustees stated that they
Would not pursue charges brought against the Towson
State College
Chapter of the Students for a Democratic Society by Vice
President
elect and Governor Spiro T. Agnew.
In a mid-October campaign speech, Agnew had charged
two
Towson professors with sponsoring what Agnew called
"an
organization dedicated to anarchy."
In the speech, delivered in Detroit, Agnew said, "It's about
time
We began to discourage the employment
of this kind of person in
our colleges and universities."
In the Monday statement by the Board of Trustees, however,
the
Board said it "has received no evidence that would justify any
action
against any faculty member of Towson State or the student
organization or the individual students."
"The Board reaffirms its confidence in Dr. Hawkins and
his
administratinn "

Four Strip for Nixon
Four persons stripped off their clothes in the Lower Broadway
district of New York,last Monday, and handed out an "open letter"
to President-elect Nixon saying that "anatomic explosions are better
than atomic explosions."
The naked demonstrators, three men and a woman,stood on the
sidewalk for 15 minutes and were daubed with body paints by a
woman who identified herself as Yayoi Kusama, a 28 year old
Japanese artist.
As a crowd of 150 people watched, Miss Kusama urged peace in
Vietnam.
One of the demonstrators said that the group had staged similar
nude "happenings" in various parts of the city.
"We've never been arrested," he said, "because the police can
never get anyone in the crowd to complain.

By PHIL SEMAS
(CPS) Stanford University may
be moving toward a change in its
relationship with the Stanford
Research Institute (SRI), which is
known to do military research.
Acting Stanford President
Robert J. Glaser has set up a
committee of five ,faculty
members, five students, and two
administrators to study Stanford's
relationship with SRI. The
Institute is an independent,
non-profit organization affiliated
with the University.
Glaser announced his plans for
the study at an unusual
appearance before the student
legislatu'r'e. He said the
relationship "is one of concern to
many members of the faculty and
student body," but added, "the
issues are complex, with many
ramifications, and are not the
kind that can be resolved
overnight".
Up Against the Door
Earlier, in an interview with the
Stanford Daily, Glaser said the
relationship "is a legitimate issue
to examine—not one to sweep
under the rug and say it doesn't
exist".
He said the incoming Stanford
President, Kenneth Pitzer,
supports the study. SRI Executive
Vice President Welcon Gibson
said the Institute would
"cooperate fully" with the study
which is supposed to be
completed by April 15.

Students Disrupt UConn
On Monday, November 11, over 100 student demonstrators
occupied the University of Connecticut's administration building,
saying they would not leave until amnesty was granted to four
professors and eight students involved in a protest against the Dow
Chemical Company last month.
The students roamed through the administration building
unchallenged, occupying the kitchen, administrative offices and the
conference room of the board of trustees, where they sat eating
doughnuts and drinking coffee.
Edward V. Grant, the school's Provost, said that the charge
against the professors was that they entered a room occupied by a
Dow recruiter and refused to leave, thereby obstructing a university
activity with "full knowledge" that it violated university policy.
On Monday, administrative work continued and officials made no
effort to evict the demonstrators.

Integration "Minimal"
Harold Howe, retiring after three years as U. S. Commissioner of
Education, says that his struggle to integrate public schools has been
disappointing, frustrating and "to a degree unsuccessful."
"Progress has been minimal," he told UPI. "Some 85 percent of
the Negro youngsters in the South still go to almost fully segregated
schools. In the North," he added,"the picture is much the same."
"We are still confronted with a school system in the United States
which is divided on a racial basis."
The 50-year old educator dismissed as campaign oratory
President-elect Richard Nixon's pledge that, as President, he would
not use federal money to force schools to integrate.
"I don't want to get into an argument with him because I don't
think the remarks he made were really carefully examined."

HC ANSWERS
To The Editors:
The article last week in Veritas
by Howard Katz was an excellent
and insightful analysis of several
of the problems in our Honor
System. The Commission is very
concerned with these issues and
we are attempting to develop
viable solutions in our regular
meetings. Certainly the answers
are not simple and it is quite
helpful to receive the thoughts
and opinions of other concerned
individuals, such as Mr. Katz.
Mr. Katz presents the need for
the Commission to become more
"The Student's Honor
Commission," and suggests the
idea that a student should have
the option to submit his case to
the professor involved or to the
Honor Commission. This specific
idea has real value and is being
considered by the Commission in
committee. At an open meeting in
the near future it shall be fully
discussed and the Commission
hopes that all concerned members
of the community will
participate. Another problem in
the Commission related to the
idea of being more for "the
students" is the selection of
Honor Commission members.
Currently we are examining more
representative and appropriate
selection procedures and again we

would consider invaluable the
participation and contribution of
the community.
Mr. Katz also proposes that a
student should be able to report a
"course or a professor for
allowing cheating," either through
negligence or the structure of the
course. This is an excellent idea,
the mechanics for it do exist, and
it has been done in the past. If a
student feels there has been
cheating in a course, whether or
not he has factual knowledge of a
specific incident, he should report
it to the Commission. In the
Commission's investigation, then,
the problem is discussed with the
professor involved, and even if an
honor violation is not discovered,
the professor becomes aware of
the problematic situation. This
idea is really only one aspect of a
vital question now facing the
Commission. How far should the
Commission's authority reach in
attempting to influence and
further the academic environment
at Hopkins? Is the Commission's
place to encourage professors or
students to direct their academic
experience towards ideals
consistent with an Honor System
and a free learning atmosphere?
Or rather is the Commission
limited only to handling honor
violations when they arise?
Beyond these questions of general

aims, of course, are the practical
concerns for their realization.
This, then, is what we consider to
be the major problem the Honor
Commission faces and again
would encourage discussion
throughout the community.
Our next open meeting shall be
December 8, and I would like to
extend a personal invitation to
Mr. Katz, the Newsletter, and all
interested Hopkins' students,
faculty and administration.
Charles Steinberg
Honor Commission Chairman

Still Looking
The Students for a Democratic Society has grown both nationally
and locally over the past year; Hopkins SDS leaders attest to this,
even the New York Times noted the national growth in an article last
Sunday. It still garners a large share of publicity in its position as the
vanguard of the "movement." Yet, for those of us whose
frustrations grew during political 1968, what has it offered in the
way of an alternative? In what ways has SDS succeeded in
challenging what we see to be faults in our society?
On Election Day, SDS staged a demonstration in Washington and
other major cities across the United States. In Washington, they
succeeded in getting over a hundred people "busted." We say
"succeeded," because this clearly was necessary if SDS's objectives
were to be realized. Merely having a thousand people "voting with
their feet" would have done previous little to point up a choiceless
election; so people had to get arrested, Chicago-style.
In SDS's interpretation, the arrests show the "naked force" upon
which our system is based. And, perhaps, herein lies the limits of
SDS's capability as an alternative. SDS had no chance of any
measure of success insofar as influencing public opinion unless
authorities responded in a way that could be construed as repression.
So ... over a hundred people get arrested, a point is made about the
"system," -- what next?
At the risk of bringing down SDS's collective sneer of
"counter-revolutionary," we really cannot decipher "what is next"
as far as the SDS program of alternatives go. Possibly, as they claim,
they have succeeded in waking up or "radicalizing" more people.
However, it seems more likely that the Chicago police and the
cynicism of the major political parties has accomplished that
without much help from SDS.
Who has SDS succeeded in politicalizing? So far as can be
observed, only the middle-class white student who can presently
afford to be radicalized. SDS has had damn little effect on the black
people or the poor people. It can be pathetic sometimes to hear
Hopkins SDS members nostalgically point out how they started
UJOIN years ago — UJOIN being an inner city organization aimed at
helping the city's black people. Have they then succeeded in
appealing to the poor whites? Unfortunately, they have been a poor
• rival to George Wallace in this area.
As far as perceivable change is concerned, it seems that SDS has
only succeeded in titillating its own followers. The SDS script reads
like a staged play where the tool runs back and forth across the stage
screaming "Confrontation!" After the confrontation, then what?
What we see is a lot of frenetic activity and rhetoric,(as usually is
the case with rhetoric, it falls on deaf ears). SDS has failed to touch
the human, it has not helped to provide those in our society who
need help with means for bettering their lot, it has failed in its intent
to educate those who still believe that all is well in America. Instead,
SDS labors to analyze America with a semi-Marxist technique
despite the fact that the institutions they criticize fail to fit into
their given categories. The result is not only irrelevancy, but a failure
to intelligently convince those whom SDS looks to as potential
followers.
The Port Huron statement, issued at the birth of SDS, was a
discerning attempt to begin to develop a convincing and coherent
critique of America's problems. Whether one sympathizes with SDS
or not, it is obvious that they have failed to follow up on the
objectives which that statement outlined, or the tone which it set.
SDS has failed to provide students, or anybody else, with an
alternative that could be worked for, or even a goal which could be
realistically achieved.
Perhaps after the fabled "revolution," SDS might have something
to say; but that revolution is very fabled and perhaps that is where
the failings of SDS lie.

By JOHN HALPERIN
"Relevance" is a word we are
beginning to hear again and again
these days; it seems that all things
under the sun must stand or fall
on the basis of how "relevant"
they are. A recent New Yorker
cartoon, for example, showed a
student making a citizen's arrest
on a businessman for irrelevance.
Perhaps the increasing importance
of Relevance as a measure of
value is a result of this year's
political campaign; all six
candidates were to my mind
overwhelmingly irrelevant, and
undoubtedly their grey reflections
have shrouded the rest of us with
the question of what is relevant in
.1968 and what is not.
If Relevance is a'nattional issue,
it must of course also be one here
at Hopkins, which is in so many
ways a relevant "establishment"
oasis. I find myself in complete
agreement with the News-Letter,
for example, on the subjects of
R.O.T.C. and university defense
contracts. Neither, it seems to me,
has any relevance to the proper
functions and goals of a
self-respecting university. The
existence of either one or both
on any campus is, I think,
evidence that the university is
doing nothing whatsoever to help
diminish—is, in fact, helping to
perpetuate--war, the defense
establishment, and aggressive and

I

unenlightened foreign policies, all
of which ought to be among any
university's major targets for
oblivion.
I think any university
administration which reacts with
horror and threats to student
demonstrations or the suggestion
of them is in danger of becoming
not only irrelevant but obsolete.
Dr. Gordon has been guilty of
some of this, perhaps due to his
education in Lyndon Johnson's
State Department (the epitome of
Irrelevance); but Dr. Gordon
seems to have learned, lately, that
however appealing a university
without any students in it might
seem, it would not indeed be a
university. In the echelons just
below Dr. Gordon's--that
mysterious realm wherein several
hundred deans or so exist—there
seems to be, more consistently at
least, a laudably realistic and
compassionate attitude toward
student desires and needs, with
the result that the student now
has more influence upon his own
existence here than ever before.
On example of this is the decision
last year to establish an Appeals
Board for the freshman
dormitories, which would hear
complaints from domitory
students on disciplinary matters.
The Board itself, however, is
rapidly in danger of becoming
irrelevant; it has never met.

I also find guilty of Irrelevance
Dr. Eisenhower's Commission on
Violence, student-faculty
coffee-hours, the Ayn Rand
Society, Mr. Kravitt's recent
article on Joe Cowan, and
Thomas F. McDonough, whoever
he is.
People say the Student Council
is irrelevant, but J am not sure.
think it must be less irrelevant
than in past years. If it has made
mistakes this year, at least it
occasionally reminds us that it
exists. I find this year's
Orientation Committee, which
will not let us forget that it exists,
almost excruciatingly relevant; for
once we are seeing a truly creative
approach being taken with regard
to the question of the university
student's relationship to
essentially non-university
problems and issues. And I find
courses like "War in the Modern
World" relevant, courses that have
something to tell us about the
world we live in and are not
satisfied with asking us to define
"culture".
I find the News-Letter in
general, and Mr. Grauer's cartoons
in particular, relevant, and on rare
occasions--most often on
weekends—I even find myself
relevant; readers of this article
and my Friday afternoon
students, however, may well
disagree.

Titanic Two Tight Lipped I

By RICHARD B.CRAMER
The Academic Council is the
most influential policy making
body on the Homewood campus.
The Council has two kinds of
meetings; the first is a formal
meeting at which resolutions or
motions are adopted and become
the policy of the University. The
second is an informal meeting,
during which issues are discussed
and accord reached so that
motions may be passed at the
next formal meeting.
On Tuesday, November 12, the
Council held an informal meeting,
to discuss "the role of students in
University policy-making." In
what amounts to a major
concession on the part of the
administration, two
undergraduates were invited to
attend. These students, Russell
Passarella (Remember? Inventive,
forceful RRRRussss?) and
Michael Amey (another campus
leader) were to serve as the
representatives of the student
body at the meeting.
Let us examine the
philo-political basis for this type
of representation. Naturally, the
Academic Council could not
entertain at its meeting, the views
of the entire student body. The
meeting would have become too
lengthy and too many students in
one place makes administrators
queasy anyway. So the Council
turned to your and our elected
leaders, the Student Council.
O.K.?

Fine, all a scale model of
Washington. But now let us cast
an eye on how this system works
in fact. Think back over the
months since you came to school.
Were you consulted as to your
opinion on the students' role at
Hopkins? Did you know that the
Academic Council was to grapple
with this question? Did you know
by whom you were to be
represented and how to make
your views known to them?
All right, we ask you for a
suspension of disbelief, now, and
suggest that you were, in fact,
amply represented at that
meeting. Suppose that by some
quirk of mass psychology, Mssrs.
Passarella and Amey represented
perfectly the view of the majority
of Hopkins students, even
without having consulted them.
We suspect that you would
want to know how your perfectly
represented views were received
by a group of men which is to
draw major policy guidelines on
the subject. There are two easy
ways to inform the students.
First, the members of the Council
could have asked a reporter from
the News-Letter to be present.
Not only was such a request not
made, but the News-Letter was
told that any of its staff members
would not be granted admission
to the meeting.
Second, our able
representatives could have taxed
their memories to the extent that
the News-Letter might have
printed the events of the meeting

to the best of their recollection.
Consulted early Tuesday evening,
Mr. Amey and a News-Letter
reporter conducted a conversation
thus: (Mr. Amey's remarks are
those erroneously labelled "A")
Q. Mike, could you tell tne
whether or not there were
any other students at this
meeting besides Russ and
yourself'?
A. There were two other graduate
students.
Q. What was the purpose of the
meeting?
A. Just to discuss the general role
of- the student in the
University.
Q. Was anything decided?
A. No, it was a very general and
relaxed discussion.
Q. Is anything going to come of
this meeting?
A. It was just a convenient basis
for an exchange of ideas, a
dialogue.
Q. Did you discuss student
participation in any
particular facet of the
University?
A. No,we didn't specify any
particular part of the
University, just general
points of information.
Q. What are these general points
of information?
A. What position students should
have in policy making in the
future.
Mr. Amey also did not know
when or if the Acadeniic Council
would again discuss this issue. We
thanked Mr. Amey for his help,

Sakowich was resting as he was

He was in the process of sifting

trying to make a decision about

mental analogy between Chicago
and Auschwitz, he noted that the
mail had arrived. Walking out to
the mailbox every day had
become a chore, and besides,
Sakowich was anxiously awaiting
his membership card in the
Teamsters. The letter that day
was not to be that delightful. It
was a letter from his draft board.
It was simply a letter for
reclassification of his draft status.
It took about five minutes to fill
out. Sakowich made the point
that he was a full-time student in
an accredited University. He
mailed the letter off immediately,
and went on in his preparations
for school.
His first hint that some
mistakes may have been made was
When his father called on a Friday
afternoon after registration was
completed. His father said—
"Hi, son, got a letter from the
*aft board today. You're 1-A."
"Oh, I see," his son replied.

appeal. At this point he was
rather confident that the mistake
would be rectified. He had
appealed in three days and was
allowed thirty.
The next day Sakowich again
received a phone call from his
father. He said—
"Hi son, I got another letter
from the draft board today.
You're ordered to take your
preinduction physical."
This time his son didn't say
anything.
He had not even been given
enough time to appeal. So
Sakowich wrote yet another letter
to his draft board. This time the
letter was not so polite.
Because his draft board was in
Virginia, and Sakowich thought it
rather ridiculous to appear in
person for a physical. So when he
received no reply from his letters
to Virginia, he decided to call the
draft board.

Although its name is rarely
heaxd around the Homewood
-campua4 the Hopkins Debate

award. The Hopkins debaters have
attended additional tournaments
at Brandeis, Emory, Rosemont,
Lasalle, and Brown.
Anyone interested in
participating in debate is urged to
attend meetings at 7 p.m. on
Tuesdays in the Reading Room of

The Johns Hopkins University
School of Medicine has received a
$259,652 grant from the John A.
Hartford Foundation, Inc. of New
York City for studies of lung
transplants.
Joint announcement of the
project and grant was made today
by Ralph W. Burger, Foundation
president, and Dr. David E.
Rogers, vice president for
medicine and dean of the medical
faculty at Johns Hopkins. Dr. R.
Robinson Baker, associate
professor of surgery, will direct
the project.
Dr. Baker said the transplant of
the human lung is technically
feasible and has actually been
attempted a number of times. In
his opinion, however, further
attempts should wait until several
basic problems have been solved
in the laboratory.
Within the past 10 years,
extensive experience with
transplantation of the lung in
experimental animals has been
accumulated.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 15, 1968

Engineering and Science at IBM

"You're treated
like a professional
right from the start'
"The attitude here is, if you're good enough to be
hired, you're good enough to be turned loose on a
project," says Don Feistamel.
Don earned a B.S.E.E. in 1965. Today, he's an
Associate Engineer in systems design and evaluation at IBM. Most of his work consists of determining modifications needed to make complex
data processing systems fit the specialized
requirements of IBM customers.
Depending on the size of the project, Don
works individually or in a small team. He's
now working with three other engineers on
part of an air traffic control system that will
process radar information by computer.
Says Don:"There are only general guidelines. The assignment is simply to come
up with the optimum system."
Set your own pace
Recently he wrote a simulation program that
enables an IBM computer to predict the performance of a data processing system that will
track satellites. He handled that project himself. "Nobody stands over my shoulder,- Don
says. "I pretty much set my own pace."
Don's informal working environment is typical of Engineering and Science at IBM. No
matter how large the project, we break it
down into units small enough to be handled
by one person or a few people.
Don sees a lot of possibilities for the future.
He says,"My job requires that I keep up to
date with all the latest IBM equipment and
systems programs. With that broad an outlook,
I can move into almost any technical area at
IBM—development, manufacturing, product
test, space and defense projects, programming
or marketing."
Check with your placement office
If you're interested in engineering or science at IBM,
ask your placement office for more information.
Or send a resume or letter to Paul Koslow, IBM
Corporation, Dept. C,425 Park Avenue, New York,
N.Y. 10022. We'd like to hear from you even if
you're headed for graduate school or military service.
An Equal Opportunity Employer

Thus far during the season, the
Blue Jays have built up a
reputation for introducing one
play a game that is so unexpected
that it is likely to change the
complexion of the entire contest.
And now all these plays are part
of a vast repetoire of surprise
tactics likely to be unveiled
tomorrow.
Key Plays
Off the wingback reverse came
the wingback reverse with
quick-kick, then the fake
quick-kick, and the wingback
reverse option-pass. Reverses on
kickoffs, dangerously exciting
wide pitchouts, and safety blitzes
are all part of the Jay arsenal.
New to this season is the
development of the fullback
position (filled by Mark Croft)
into an expanded role that
includes, in addition to blocking,
its own belly series up the middle
and a number of swing and screen
pass patterns.
Particularly valuable to the
basic Jay offense is the option
play (diagrammed here) in which
Feely, running parallel to the line
of scrimmage has the choice of
cutting upfield himself or pitching
to Cowan outside for a wide
sweep. The choice is based on
whether the unblocked outside
defender (No. 45) commits
himself to the inside or the
outside.
In amassing a 5-2 record, the
basic offensive pattern has been a
balanced mixture of Weiss inside
(with help from Croft) Cowan on
sweeps and counters (coming
back against the flow) and Feely

Clumsy PMC Squad
Last Friday, in their first home
game of the current season, the
freshman football team defeated
an inept and clumsy squad from
PMC Colleges of Chester, Pa., by
the score of 44-15.
From the opening kickoff to
the anticlimatic fourth quarter
there was not even the slightest
shread of doubt about the
outcome. The game began with a
fumble
by PMC Captain
Richie Weaver on the kickoff. Our
men thus had the good fortune to
begin play with the ball on the
oPponent's 5 yard line. On the
second play from scrimmage,
Steve Utz scurried into the end
zone for the first of his 3 ID's.
The extra points were missed and
the score was 6-0.
Weaver held on to the next
kickoff, and ran it back to the 30.
In the next three plays PMC was
only able to move several yards,
and so had to punt. Guard Bud
Cleveland, after a great rushing
exhibition, got his body in front
of the kick, from whence it
caromed to the PMC 11, where
Hopkins took over. On the next
Play, Bud Whalen floated the ball
to Steve Utz for another score.
On the screen, Joe Cieslowslci got
the extra points to make the score
14-0.
Once again, PMC managed to
hold on to the kickoff, and after
getting the premier first down of
the game, and after marching out
to their own 30, had to kick. The

ball's flight was unfettered this
time, but it didn't matter since it
was straight up into the air. When
the ball finally bounced out of
bounds the kick amounted to
minus five yards.
On the next play, Bud Whalen
threw the "perfect pass" to Dave
Pickall for the third TD out of
four bffensive plays, certainly a
great show of offensive power.
There was no more scoring
until the middle of the second
quarter when PMC recovered• a
fumble on the home 29 and
marched in to score on a 1 yard
QB sneak. They kicked for the
conversion. A Hopkins march was
then culminated by a five yard
score by Utz, his third TD. A
Whalen to Pickall 2 pointer
finished the scoring for the half
with the score 28-7.
The second half began where
the first half left off, with an 18
yard touchdown pass from Bud
Whalen to Dave Pickall, with
Butch Robey adding the two
points.
The Hopkins scoring finished
when Jeff Turshen pounded over
from the one after a 37 yard set
up run by Robey. Halfback Rich
Weaver then showed the speed
which had coach Bob Scott
worried, on a 70 yard pass play in
which he left the entire Hopkins
secondary behind.
The last game of the season
will take place today against the
Towson StateVarsity.

The results of the BIA tennis
tournament were: Sig Ep over Phi
Gam in the fraternities; Willard
over Wood in the upperclass
dorms; and Gildersleeve over
Adams in the freshmen dorms. Sig
Ep's Bob Tigner and Jim
Bernstein were the winning
fraternity doubles team. Winning
entrants for Willard were Simon
Tonkin and Stan Konefal. In
frosh competition, John Fischer
and Steve Kane teamed up to win
for Gildersleeve.
Basketball

Basketball will begin the week
of December 2. Any grad students
and independents who want to
form teams should contact Col.
Serena at the Athletic office.
Officials will be needed in large
numbers because of each teams'
increased schedules. Anyone
, interested in refereeing should
look for further notices in the
' BIA's scandal sheet, the gym, and
the News-Letter. Freshmen
refereeing will not conflict with
their playing for their respective
house. As of yet, the formal
schedules and league divisions
have not been made up by the
BIA.

the Charles Division, not ZBT.
The football schedule, especially
the fraternity playoffs and frosh
football, have been thrown off
base by the recent weather. Rain
and snow forced two
postponements of the Northern
Division playoff between ATO

season play, each house beat the
other once. TEP took the first
contest 15-6, but ATO came back
in the second encounter to win
19-18 in the final minutes of play.

ambiguities or discrepancies in the
BIA football rules and has any
criticisms or possible changes in
the rules is asked to drop a note
in Box 418, Gene Detroyer.

Our upstart congregation is too young and too small to
identify with the status quo. Founded in 1849, we have
only 6,000 members world-wide. Perhaps that is why,
responding to the needs of the changing times, we find it
easy to move out to where the action is. Among our favorite
assignments are the inner city and missions in Latin
America, where there's no shortage of injustice to confront.
We believe that Christianity, in the tradition of the early
, martyrs, must be somewhat anti-Establishment in every
age. We don't lock up our zealous young men for taking
this idea seriously. If you agree, we invite you to march
with us. Put down your brick and contact our vocations
director, Father Lawrence Hoge. Phone (312) 236-7782.
